results.title: With ‘Summer of Soul,’ Questlove Wants to Fill a Cultural Void
results.abstract: “This just sat in a basement and no one cared,” Questlove said about the Harlem Cultural Festival footage he watched on loop for months to make his new, acclaimed documentary.

results.title: When Truth Melds With Fiction: Making ‘I Carry You With Me’

results.title: It’s Not Easy Being Greenspeople
results.abstract: Transforming winter into spring or creating faux forests and fanciful estates is all in a day’s work for these behind-the-scenes masters of foliage on movie and TV sets.

results.title: Lydia Lunch’s Infinite Rebellion
results.abstract: “Good luck figuring me out,” the 62-year-old artist said. A new documentary called “The War Is Never Over” does its best.

multimedia.caption: “It’s the problems that are nihilistic, not me,” Lydia Lunch said. “I’m the most positive person I know.”

results.title: Robert Sacchi, Who Played Bogart Again and Again, Dies at 89
results.abstract: He was a hard-working actor and not merely a doppelgänger. But his claim to fame on film, TV and the stage was that he looked like Bogie.

results.title: Taylour Paige on ‘Zola,’ Grace and Being Kinder to Herself
results.abstract: For the stripper tale, the actress was mindful of the real Zola’s voice: “We’re in service of the bigger truth, the way we as Black women go through the world.”

multimedia.caption: “Zola” is just the latest major film for Taylour Paige in the last year or so. She said, “When I hear ‘breakthrough,’ it is like, ‘OK, but what’s expected of me? What’s expected of Black women?’”
multimedia.copyright: Chantal Anderson for The New York Times
